) Office of Employee Protection (OEP) Mission: To effectively administer programs tracking potentially dangerous taxpayers and those taxpayers that Scope and should be approached with caution. (
) Purpose: This IRM section provides information on OEP and describes the Potentially Dangerous Taxpayer (PDT) program and PDT reporting process. (
) Audience: The information and procedures in this IRM apply to all IRS employees with duties requiring taxpayer contact. (
) Program Owner: The Chief, Office of Employee Protection, reports to the Associate Director, Incident Management and Employee Protection, and oversees the PDT program. (
) Contact Information: To recommend changes to this IRM, see IRM Providing Feedback About an IRM Section - Outside of Clearance, and your suggestions to the *PGLD OEP mailbox. (

, the IRS Commissioner assigned IRS Inspection the responsibility developing a program to improve the Service’s ability to identify taxpayers represent a potential danger to employees. Inspection developed the tially Dangerous Taxpayer (PDT) program, which included the PDT database. Inspection was then given responsibility for administering the program. (
) Inspection became the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) in

Most of Inspection’s previous duties, including the tion of the PDT program, were transferred to TIGTA. Due to TIGTA’s role and responsibilities, however, it was agreed that the administration and maintenance of the PDT program be transferred back to the IRS. ) The following subsections detail OEP’s and TIGTA’s speciﬁc roles and sibilities within the PDT program. Roles (

) OEP administers the PDT program by: • Reviewing and analyzing TIGTA’s Reports of Investigation (ROI’s) • Making a determination as to whether or not PDT criteria have been met • Inputting and removing the PDT indicator to and from the Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) Master File and/or Non-Master File accounts • Maintaining the PDT section of the Employee Protection System e-Trak Database • Functioning as liaison with General Legal Services (GLS) • Providing information and feedback to referring employees and their spective IRS managers • Performing PDT ﬁve-year reviews

) The following terms and deﬁnitions are provided to clarify terminology used the PDT program: a. Assault: Direct physical contact, with the intent to cause physical including striking or attempting to strike with objects, such as rocks or bottles, or brandishing a weapon. b. Threat: Verbal or written expression of intent to cause harm to an IRS employee or contractor or to an IRS employee’s or contractor’s immediate family member. It also includes preventing an IRS employee or contractor from leaving a taxpayer’s business or residence, even if physical contact actually occurs. c. Intimidate: Action intended to cause an IRS employee or contractor to become timid, or to force or deter an IRS employee or contractor from taking actions. d. Nexus to Tax Administration: A taxpayer who has some type of open activity or reasonable prospect of future activity on their or their busi- ness’s IDRS Master File or Non-Master File account, or a taxpayer even one with no open activity or reasonable prospect of future activity, initiates contact with the Service or any other tax administration

) Taxpayers must be identiﬁed by Social Security Numbers (SSN) and/or Employer Identiﬁcation Numbers (EIN). (
) Association with a PDT or membership in a group, some of whose advocate violent protest against our tax system, does not by itself fulﬁll the criteria for designation as a PDT. (

An IRS employee, who is assigned a case for which there is a POA and will be contact with that POA, has a “business need to know” whether the has been designated as a PDT or CAU. The IRS employee can utilize IDRS ascertain whether the POA has been designated as a PDT or a CAU, just as the IRS employee does for any taxpayer, as long as the IRS employee does not access any of the POA’s other tax information. IDRS Command Code “ENMOD” can be used to determine if the POA has been designated as either a PDT or a CAU. If an IRS employee does not know the POA’s SSN and/or EIN needed to utilize “ENMOD”, he/she can use Command Codes “NAMES” or “NAMEI” to obtain the POA’s SSN - OR - “NAMEE” or “NAMEB” to obtain the POA’s EIN. ) A PDT indicator will remain on a taxpayer’s IDRS Master File and/or Non- Master File account for ﬁve years, at which time, the status will be Review of PDT by an OEP Specialist. (

) Any taxpayer, who has been designated as a PDT and meets one or more the following renewal criteria, will retain the PDT indicator for an additional year period: a. An additional PDT referral was made during the ﬁve-year period review; b. The PDT offense was a physical assault on an IRS employee or tor; c. An arrest by TIGTA or other law enforcement agencies, for a threat to an assault on an IRS employee or contractor, occurred during the year period under review; or d. There is current IRS activity at the time of the review. (
) If the taxpayer does not meet the above renewal criteria, an OEP will remove the PDT indicator from that taxpayer’s IDRS Master File and/or Non-Master File account.
